Fig 8 PIM-1 as an artificial solid electrolyte interphase for stable lithium metal anode in high-performance batteries Qiuli Yang a Wenli Li a Chen Dong a Yuyan Ma a Yuxin Yin a Qibing Wu b Zhitao Xu b Wei Ma a Cheng Fan a ⁎ Kening Sun a ⁎ a Beijing Key Laboratory for Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China Beijing Key Laboratory for Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Beijing Institute of Technology Beijing 100081 China aBeijing Key Laboratory for Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China b State Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Power Sources, Guizhou Meiling Power Sources Co. Ltd., Zunyi 563003, Guizhou, China State Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Power Sources Guizhou Meiling Power Sources Co. Ltd. Zunyi Guizhou 563003 China bState Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Power Sources, Guizhou Meiling Power Sources Co. Ltd., Zunyi 563003 Guizhou, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Lithium metal anode is a promising electrode with high theoretical specific capacity and low electrode potential. However, its unstable interface and low Coulombic efficiency, resulting from the dendritic growth of lithium, limits its commercial application. PIM-1 (PIM: polymer of intrinsic microporosity), which is a polymer with abundant micropores, exhibits high rigidity and flexibility with contorted spiro-centers in the backbone, and is an ideal candidate for artificial solid electrolyte interphases (SEI). In this work, a PIM-1 membrane was synthesized and fabricated as a protective membrane on the surface of an electrode to facilitate the uniform flux of Li ions and act as a stable interface for the lithium plating/stripping process. Nodule-like lithium with rounded edges was observed under the PIM-1 membrane. The Li@PIM-1 electrode delivered a high average Coulombic efficiency (99.7%), excellent cyclability (80% capacity retention rate after 600 cycles at 1 C), and superior rate capability (125.3 mAh g−1 at 10 C). Electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS) showed that the PIM-1 membrane could lower the diffusion rate of Li+ significantly and change the rate-determining step from charge transfer to Li+ diffusion. Thus, the PIM-1 membrane is proven to act as an artificial SEI to facilitate uniform and stable deposition of lithium, in favor of obtaining a compact and dense Li-plating pattern. This work extends the application of PIMs in the field of lithium batteries and provides ideas for the construction of artificial SEI. Graphical abstract PIM-1 was employed as a protective membrane on the surface of an electrode to facilitate the uniform flux of Li+ ions. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lithium metal anodes Artificial solid electrolyte interphase PIM-1 Diffusion-limited 1 Introduction With the increasing demand for electric vehicles and mobile electronics, traditional lithium-ion batteries have become incapable of meeting the high energy-density requirements of consumers [1–3]. The lithium metal anode is considered as the ultimate electrode, owing to its high theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and low electrochemical potential [4–6] (−3.040 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode). However, the dendritic growth of lithium during cycling often leads to short-circuits, sometimes causing catastrophic problems for lithium metal batteries [7–10]. The inhomogeneous distribution of the electric field, arising from the rough surface of the current collector, always leads to inhomogeneous nucleation and tip growth of lithium [11–15], which penetrates the separator because of its high strength and needle-like morphology. Meanwhile, the dendrite growth of lithium increases the specific area of the electrode and facilitates side reactions between the electrolyte and lithium, resulting in the construction of large amount of undesirable solid electrolyte interphases (SEI) [16–18]. The cracking of the fragile dendrite and repeated breaking/growth of the SEI film consumes the lithium metal, causing isolation of lithium and decreasing the Coulombic efficiency of the batteries [19,20]. Many strategies have been proposed to solve these problems, from the aspects of nucleation and growth of lithium dendrites. One technique aims to achieve a homogeneous distribution of lithiophilic sites by introducing lithiophilic groups on the surface of the electrode [21–26] to account for uniform Li nucleation. Changing the growth pattern of the initial protuberances, from tip-growth to side-growth, is another method that aims at suppressing the growth of lithium dendrites. In another technique, cations with low reduction potentials [27] are employed as additives in the electrolyte to form a positively charged electrostatic shield around the tip to enable smooth deposition. The use of vertical nanoscale channels of high aspect ratio [28–30], solvent-in-salt electrolytes with high-concentration of salt [31,32], and solid electrolytes with high modulus [33–36] are also effective approaches for achieving nondendritic growth. However, the construction of a stable electrolyte/electrode interface remains a critical challenge, as the strategies for the prevention of lithium dendrite growth are not always efficient. This is mainly because of the native SEI, which separates the electrolyte from the lithium electrode physically, but is too fragile to account for long cycling. A robust artificial SEI with high mechanical strength, flexibility, and ionic conductivity is thus desirable. Nevertheless, these properties are hardly to be achieved simultaneously, and several attempts have been devised from different angles. Interconnected amorphous hollow carbon nanospheres [24] with a Young's modulus of ∼200 GPa were deposited on the Li metal anode, which are weakly bound to the current collector to move up and down for Li plating/stripping and to suppress Li dendrites. This strategy achieved a high Coulombic efficiency of ∼99% with a dendrite-free morphology for more than 150 cycles at a current density of 1.0 mA cm−2 and a capacity of 1.0 mAh cm−2. An inorganic layer containing lithium compounds with Young's modulus more than 10 GPa [37,38] was also proven to be effective for suppressing the dendritic growth of lithium by mechanical resistance. Quite recently, two different composite membranes, one with single-ion conducting nature [39] and the other with high homogeneity [40], were constructed to obtain electrochemical performances with high Coulombic efficiency and considerably enhanced cyclability. Composite films [39–41] combine the advantages of the inorganic material and the organic polymer, while the two-phase interfaces always propagate into cracks during cycling. Polymers of intrinsic microporosity (PIMs) are a class of organic polymers with rigid and contorted spiro-centers in the backbone, which inhibit efficient packing of macromolecules in the solid state, resulting in microporosity. The abundant, interconnected, and permanent micropores enable the wide application of PIMs in gas separation [42–45], adsorption [46], and electronic devices [47]. However, its application in the field of lithium batteries has seldom been reported. As organic materials with rigid chains, PIMs exhibit both rigidity and flexibility [48], which is in accordance with the requirements of an ideal artificial SEI. The micropores, mostly with diameters of approximately 0.4–0.8 nm [49–51], are uniformly distributed in the polymer matrix and construct an isotropic channel network for the diffusion of Li+ ions. In this contribution, PIM-1, was synthesized and fabricated as a protective membrane on the surface of an electrode, to guide uniform flux of Li ions and act as a stable interface for lithium plating/stripping (Fig. 1 ). PIM-1, with ether groups in the main chains, is supposed to be swollen by both ether and carbonate-based solvents when soaked in the electrolyte. It traps the solvent and large anion molecules in the network and micropores to serve as a medium for the transport of the Li ions. The immobilization of the solvent and anions enables high-efficiency Li+ diffusion in the channels and ensures proper isolation between the electrolyte and the lithium metal, preventing side reactions, to some extent. The uniform Li+ flux through the isotropic channel network onto the surface of the electrode is expected to be in favor of obtaining a compact and dense Li-plating pattern. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of PIM-1 5,5′,6,6′-tetrahydroxy-3,3,3′,3′-tetramethyl-1,1′-helical-dipheny-lindene(2.2475 g, 0.0066 mol), tetrafluoro-phenylene diacetonitrile (1.3209 g, 0.0066 mol), and dry dimethylformamide (DMF, 42.3 mL) were added to a dry 250 mL three-necked round-bottom flask equipped with a condenser, inert gas inlet, and magnetic stirrer. Anhydrous potassium carbonate (7.75 g, 0.05615 mol) was added to the mixture and the temperature was maintained at 65 °C at 300 rpm under nitrogen atmosphere for 68 h. On cooling, the crude product was obtained by vacuum filtration, which was then washed with dimethylformamide, acetone, and deionized water, in turn, thrice. To purify the product, 200 mL of 1,4-dioxane was used to dissolve the filter cake. After purification, the filter cake was washed using acetone, deionized water, and dioxane again. The final product was dried in vacuum at 95 °C overnight. 2.2 Fabrication of artificial protective PIM-1 membrane 0.02 g of yellow PIM-1 power was dissolved in 1.98 g of dry N-methyl pyrrolidone to form a dilute solution with a concentration of 2 wt.%. The dispersion was magnetically stirred for 24 h at 25 °C. 10 µL of the solution was dispersed on a clean copper/lithium foil. Then, the coated foil was placed on a horizontal stand and vacuumed under a constant vapor pressure to prevent the shrinkage of the surface from the edges, thereby ensuring consistent thickness of the coating. All the above operations were conducted in a glove box (Mbraun, H2O < 0.1 ppm, O2 < 0.1 ppm). The copper foil covered evenly with PIM-1 (denoted as Cu@PIM-1) of 2 wt.% was dried in vacuum at 120 °C overnight and the lithium foil covered with PIM-1 (denoted as Li@PIM-1) of 2 wt.% was dried in a glove box at room temperature for 7 days. 2.3 Preparation of LiFePO4 cathode LiFePO4 powder, super P carbon, and PVDF in the weight ratio of 8:1:1 were mixed in N-methyl pyrrolidone to form a slurry. The slurry was blade-coated on Al foils and dried at 100 °C in vacuum. After drying, the LiFePO4 electrodes were punched into disks of diameter 9 mm. The typical mass loading of active materials for the LiFePO4 electrodes was approximately 2 mg cm−2. 2.4 Fabrication of batteries For the Cu|Li battery, 2025-type coin cells were assembled with bare Li foils (Ф12 mm) as the anode, and Cu foils (Ф18 mm) covered with PIM-1 membrane served as the cathode. The electrolyte was composed of 1.0 M lithium bis(trifluor-omethanesulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) in 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) (1:1 by volume) with lithium nitrate of 2 wt.%. The cells were tested by depositing 1 mAh cm−2 of Li onto the Cu foil, followed by Li stripping up to 0.5 V. For the Li|LiFePO4 battery, 2025-type coin cells were assembled with Li foils (Ф12 mm, the thickness of the Li foil was 0.75 mm) covered with PIM-1 membrane as the anode and LiFePO4 disks as the cathode. The electrolyte was composed of 1.0 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC) (1:1 by volume). The voltage range of the Li|LiFePO4 batteries was from 2 to 4.2 V, for the galvanostatic charge–discharge test. Additionally, to standardize the measurement, the amount of the electrolyte added to each cell was controlled to 50 µL, and the cells were packed using a sealing machine (MSK-110) at a pressure of 50 kg cm−2. The whole process of battery fabrication was performed in an argon-filled glove box (Mbraun, H2O < 0.1 ppm, O2 < 0.1 ppm) and all cells were tested using the Land battery testing system (LAND CT-2001A) at room temperature. 2.5 Characterization The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) analysis was conducted using an FT-IR spectrometer of Thermo IS5. The thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed at a heating rate of 10.0 °C min−1 from 30 to 900 °C in N2 using a Metter Toledo TGA/DSC 1 system. The number-averaged molecular weight and weight-averaged molecular weight were measured through gel permeation chromatography (GPC) using the Waters 1515 system. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of PIM-1 were obtained using a Quantachrome instrument (ASIQM0VH002-5) at 77 K. The surface morphology of the Li anodes and PIM-1 membrane were characterized using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, FEI Quanta FEG 250). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were carried out using Biologic VSP-300. The atomic force microscopy (AFM) measurements were conducted using an Asylum Research Cypher atomic force microscope. The contact mode was used to detect the morphology of the Li anode and measure the Young's modulus of the Li anodes. The radius of the probe was 8 nm, and the spring constant of the probe was 2 N m−1. 3 Results and discussion FT-IR spectroscopy was employed to characterize the functional groups of the synthesized PIM-1 polymer. As shown in Fig. 2 , the characteristic vibrational peaks of aryl ether in the range of 1305 to 1160 cm−1 demonstrated the successful condensation polymerization, and a characteristic broad band of phenol hydroxyl groups in the range of 3200–3500 cm−1 disappeared. The peak at 2241 cm−1 corresponded to the stretching vibration of the cyano groups. The polymer exhibited good thermal stability, as an obvious weight loss was observed until approximately 470 °C (Fig. 2(b)), which was in agreement with the data from the literature [51–54]. The weight-averaged molar mass (M w) and number-averaged molar mass (M n) were analyzed to be 41.8 and 6.2 kDa, respectively, using GPC, and the polydispersity index (M w/M n) was calculated to be 6.68. The broad molecular weight distribution indicated the existence of both long chains and short chains in the obtained PIM-1 powder, which were expected to contribute the mechanical strength and free volumes respectively. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm (Fig. 2(c)) revealed a surface area of approximately 419.2 m2 g−1 from the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis which was in good agreement with the values reported in the literature [42,54,55]. The pore size distribution of the PIM-1 powder was calculated using the Horvath–Kawazoe method (Fig. 2(d)). Significant peaks were observed at 0.45 and 0.85 nm, and the cumulative pore size of the first peak gave a pore volume of 0.152 cm3 g−1, almost 77% of the total micropore volume, was much larger than previously reported [42,54]. The networks of micropores interconnected throughout the structure to form channels, which were able to swell and adsorb solvent molecules and transport Li+ ions onto the surface of the electrode [54,56]. Full N2 isotherms on the PIM-1 membrane were not performed, because of the impractically long time required by the volumetric system to equilibrate in the low-pressure ranges. The mechanical properties of the PIM-1 membrane, obtained from the wet cast method, were determined by nanoindentation experiments performed using AFM spectroscopy. The force–displacement curve (Fig. 3 (b)) showed linear deflection of the cantilever at the initial stage of loading, indicating elastic and reversible deformation. As the force increased, a leveling out was observed instead of an undesirable dip, followed by another linear trend. As the membrane was cast on a Si substrate, the two elastic deformations were both considered to be reversible deformations of PIM-1. The abundant cavities of free volume in the matrix of the PIM-1 membrane contributed to a first elastic deformation with a Young's modulus of 0.71 GPa (Fig. 3(c)), calculated from the Derjaguin–Muller–Toporov (DMT) method. The force plateau was expected to be caused by the hierarchical porous structure of the PIM-1 polymer, where partial densification occurred once the small nanopores collapsed. The compressed polymer further exhibited a linear force response, and the fitting of this curve gave a Young's modulus of 0.39 GPa (Fig. 3(c)). The different mechanical properties at various depths were related to the stiffer outer layer and more elastic inner chains of the polymer during the evaporation of the solution [57]. The retract curve exhibited only one consecutive line and almost returned back to the initial position of the approach curve, suggesting an elastic and reversible deformation of the membrane. Although the Young's modulus of the bulk polymer was lower than that previously reported [51,58,59], owing to the large polydispersity index, it still far exceeded that of native SEI (≈150 MPa). As a result, the rigid and flexible properties of the PIM-1 membrane can be expected to be more robust than that of the SEI, to resist large volume changes during repeated charge and discharge cycles. The morphology of the PIM-1 membrane was investigated using a scanning electron microscope (SEM). Fig. 4 demonstrates the surface morphology and cross-section images of the PIM-1 coating on the Cu foil. The PIM-1 membrane displayed a smooth and dense surface with few visible defects (Fig. 4(a)). These defects appeared to be round pits with diameters of ∼100 nm, formed from the evaporation of solvents, and not through-holes. The enlarged area of the surface image (Fig. 4(b)) showed a smooth and intact surface without any defects. A close examination of the cross-section revealed a uniform thickness of approximately 4.4 µm (Fig. 4(c)). As shown, the membrane was in loose contact with the current collector, from which it broke off after being frozen in liquid nitrogen. Thus, the growing Li could be expected to elevate the membrane and be deposited underneath the PIM-1 after receiving the electrons. When the membrane was coated on lithium, it could effectively prevent the diffusion of O2 and H2O onto the lithium metal. As a result, the PIM-1-coated Li foil mostly demonstrated its original color after exposure to air for two weeks (Fig. 5 (c) and (d)), whereas the bare foil (Fig. 5(a) and (b)) turned black owing to the production of Li2O, LiOH, Li2CO3, etc. However, a small amount of grey was observed for the coated Li, indicating that channels still existed in the membrane for the transfer of gas molecules. To investigate the transport properties of the membrane, for the Li+ ions, the Cu|Li coin cells were disassembled after 20 cycles at a capacity of 1.0 mAh cm−2. A large amount of lithium dendrites was found on the bare Cu cathode without PIM-1 (Fig. 5(e) and (f)). In comparison, the surface of the coated Cu (Fig. 5(g)) was still covered by an intact PIM-1 membrane with looming depositions under the PIM-1 membrane, which presented a stable and uniform interface. The deposited Li (Fig. 5(h)) exhibited nodule-like structures with rounded edges under the PIM-1 membrane, unlike the needle-like structure on the bare Cu cathode (Fig. 5(f)). This was consistent with the original design intended to guide uniform flux and construct a stable interface. The abundant micropores in the polymer matrix provided interconnected channels for the solvent molecules to swell. Li+ ions with small volume were driven by the potential difference and transported through the channels onto the surface of the electrode. Large molecules and anions were trapped in the channels with diameters of mainly 0.7 nm, and served as a medium for the diffusion of Li+ ions. Because the channels were distributed uniformly in the polymer matrix, the Li+ ion flux transported to the electrode surface was also distributed uniformly, and it was affected by only the resistance of the membrane other than the surface roughness of the electrode. Thus, a dendrite-free structure of lithium was obtained. Without sharp tips, the metallic lithium tended to grow under the membrane rather than penetrate through the membrane, and ensured a stable interface between the electrolyte and electrode. Benefitting from the stable interface constructed by the PIM-1 membrane, the Cu@PIM-1|Li cell revealed an improved performance, when compared to the bare Cu|Li cell (Fig. 6 ). At a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 and capacity of 1.0 mAh cm−2, the Cu@PIM-1|Li cell showed a Coulombic efficiency of 97% for more than 180 cycles, while the bare Cu|Li cell exhibited a rapid decay after only 70 cycles at the same current density. As the current density increased to 1.0 mA cm−2, a high Coulombic efficiency of 97% was still observed after 150 cycles for the Cu@PIM-1|Li cell, whereas, the bare Cu|Li battery exhibited total failure after the 53rd cycle. When a critical current density of 2.0 mA cm−2 was applied, a higher Coulombic efficiency and longer cycling life were still achieved, although fluctuations or irregular oscillations were observed in the Coulombic efficiency curves of both the protected and unprotected cells, indicating the presence of an extremely unstable interface at such high current densities. LiFePO4|Li cells were assembled to assess the favorable effect of the PIM-1 membrane under practical conditions. With an initial capacity exceeding 145 mAh g−1 for both protected and unprotected cells, the capacity of the bare Li|LiFePO4 cell showed a rapid decline, while the Li@PIM-1|LiFePO4 cell delivered stable cycling with a capacity retention of 89.9% over 600 cycles and an average Coulombic efficiency as high as 99.7% at 1 C (Fig. 7 (a)). The voltage profiles (Fig. 7(b)) give an insight into the origin of the improved performances of the protected cell. The voltage polarization of the bare Li|LiFePO4 cell increased from 126 to 328 mV at the 200th cycle. In comparison, the polarization voltage of the Li@PIM-1|LiFePO4 cell was slightly higher (174 mV) at the first cycle but remained constant for 200 cycles, indicating the construction of a stable interface as a result of the PIM-1 coating. This was on account of the dendrite-free morphology and isolation of lithium from the electrolyte, as confirmed in the previous SEM images. The stable interface and the subsequent constant overpotential also contributed to the achieved rate performance of the Li@PIM-1|LiFePO4 cell (Fig. 7(c)). Highly reversible capacities of 162, 160, 156, 150, and 125 mAh g−1 were obtained at various discharge rates of 0.5, 1, 2, 5, and 10 C, respectively, and the capacity recovered fully as the discharge rate returned to 2 C (26th cycle). A similar trend but with lower capacity was characterized for the unprotected cell, and significant capacity fading w' as observed during the 26th to 35th cycles. EIS was employed to further investigate the morphology and evolution of the electrode/electrolyte interface. To obtain a thorough evaluation of both Li+ transport and charge transfer, discharged Cu|Li cells with a plating density of 1.0 mAh cm−2 were employed. The Nyquist representations in the low frequency shifted from semi-circles (Fig. 8 (c)–(e)) to Warburg-like “tails” (Fig. 8(h)–(j)), as the PIM-1 membrane was coated on the Cu electrode, indicating the change of the rate-determining step from charge transfer to diffusion. The diffusion was only related to the Li+ transport near the surface of the electrode because of the absence of intercalation materials in the half cells. Considering these differences, equivalent circuits referring to theoretical circuits of the bare and protected Cu electrodes were defined as in Fig. 8(a) and (f), respectively, and the corresponding schematic diagrams of the lithium morphologies were shown in Fig. 8(b) and (g). The EIS data fitted well with the modeled impedance data over the entire frequency range. For the bare Cu|Li cells, the charge transfer resistance (R ct), given by the diameter of the right semicircle, was much higher than the SEI resistance (R SEI), given by the diameter of the high-frequency semicircle. The plating rate was controlled by the reaction rate rather than the diffusion rate. The PIM-1 membrane on the Cu electrode lowered the diffusion rate of Li+ significantly, and changed the electrode reaction into a diffusion-limited pattern. The diffusion rate of Li+ in the membrane accelerated as the slope of the low-frequency tail increased from the first cycle to the 100th cycle, which was mostly related to the propagation of channels during cycling. However, the Li+ diffusion was still the dominant step, which further suggested that the PIM-1 membrane remained intact during the lithium plating/stripping process, in accordance with the design that aimed at creating a PIM-1 membrane as an artificial SEI to enable uniform and stable deposition of lithium. 4 Conclusions A stable polymer of intrinsic microporosity, PIM-1, was synthesized and employed as an artificial SEI due to its rigidity and flexibility. The uniformly distributed micropores in the PIM-1 constructed isotropic channel network for the diffusion of Li+ ions and enabled a stable interface during the lithium plating/stripping process, preferring for a compact and dense Li plating pattern. As a result, the Li@PIM-1|LiFePO4 cells delivered a high average Coulombic efficiency (99.7%), excellent cyclability (80% capacity retention rate for 600 cycles at 1 C), and superior rate capability (125.3 mAh g−1 at 10 C). More importantly, the PIM-1 membrane on the electrode significantly lowered the diffusion rate of Li+ and changed the electrode reaction into diffusion-limited pattern, which declared a novel way for designing dendrite-free electrodes. This work extends the application of the PIMs on the field of lithium battery and provides novel ideas for the construction of artificial SEI, promoting the commercialization of the lithium metal anode battery. coredata.dc:description: Lithium metal anode is a promising electrode with high theoretical specific capacity and low electrode potential. However, its unstable interface and low Coulombic efficiency, resulting from the dendritic growth of lithium, limits its commercial application. PIM-1 (PIM: polymer of intrinsic microporosity), which is a polymer with abundant micropores, exhibits high rigidity and flexibility with contorted spiro-centers in the backbone, and is an ideal candidate for artificial solid electrolyte interphases (SEI). In this work, a PIM-1 membrane was synthesized and fabricated as a protective membrane on the surface of an electrode to facilitate the uniform flux of Li ions and act as a stable interface for the lithium plating/stripping process. Nodule-like lithium with rounded edges was observed under the PIM-1 membrane. The Li@PIM-1 electrode delivered a high average Coulombic efficiency (99.7%), excellent cyclability (80% capacity retention rate after 600 cycles at 1 C), and superior rate capability (125.3 mAh g−1 at 10 C). Electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS) showed that the PIM-1 membrane could lower the diffusion rate of Li+ significantly and change the rate-determining step from charge transfer to Li+ diffusion. Thus, the PIM-1 membrane is proven to act as an artificial SEI to facilitate uniform and stable deposition of lithium, in favor of obtaining a compact and dense Li-plating pattern. This work extends the application of PIMs in the field of lithium batteries and provides ideas for the construction of artificial SEI.
